Understate: The claim may understate the percentage of Germans who were Nazis in 1940, as the expert's verdict suggests that the claim relies on a narrow definition of who was considered a Nazi.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the stated percentage of Nazis among Germans in 1940.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption by equating the percentage of Nazis among Germans in 1940 to the current situation of extremist Muslims.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may have alternative explanations for the percentage of Nazis among Germans in 1940, such as the inclusion of supporters who did not formally join the party.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict the fact that the percentage of Nazis among Germans in 1940 was higher than the stated 7% if we consider the 6.5 million members of the Nazi party mentioned by the expert.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the percentage of Germans who were Nazis in 1940 if it only counts formal party members and excludes supporters.
